title: Quiz 9: Medical Microbiology & Immunity
description: Assess your knowledge of host-parasite interactions, the nature of disease, and the body's immune defenses.

questions.question: Match the term with its definition:

pairs.right: Ability of a parasite to inflict damage
Establishment/growth of a microbe in a host

questions.explanation: Pathogenicity is ability; Virulence is degree; Infection is presence; Disease is damage.

questions.question: An ___BLANK___ pathogen causes disease only in the absence of normal host resistance (e.g., in immunocompromised patients).
questions.explanation: Opportunistic pathogens take advantage of opportunities like weak immunity.

questions.question: When does colonization of the human body by the normal microbial flora typically begin?
questions.explanation: The womb is sterile; colonization begins at birth.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the typical infection process at a mucous membrane:
Which type of immunity is present at birth and provides non-specific resistance?
questions.explanation: Innate immunity is natural, inborn, and nonspecific.

questions.question: Match the type of adaptive immunity with its description:
questions.hint: Active means your body does the work.

questions.question: Which of the following are components of Innate Immunity? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Barriers and Phagocytes are innate. Antibodies/T-cells are adaptive.

questions.question: Infection is synonymous with disease; every infection results in disease.
questions.explanation: Infection is just the presence of the microbe; disease is when damage occurs. You can be infected without disease.
questions.hint: Carriers have infection but no disease.

questions.question: What is the term for the viscous soluble glycoproteins that coat mucous membranes?
questions.explanation: Mucus coats membranes to trap microbes.

questions.question: Which of the following creates 'Passive' immunity?
questions.explanation: Passive immunity involves receiving pre-made antibodies.
